questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of pain and swelling of his right knee joint for 1 day. He has not had any trauma to the knee. He was born at term and has been healthy since. His maternal uncle has a history of a bleeding disorder. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F) and pulse is 97/min. The right knee is erythematous, swollen, and tender; range of motion is limited. No other joints are affected. An x-ray of the knee shows an effusion but no structural abnormalities of the joint. Arthrocentesis is done. The synovial fluid is bloody. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leukocytosis and a yellowish-green appearance of synovial fluid are diagnostic features of septic arthritis, a bacterial infection of the joint space. The infection presents with a triad of fever, joint pain, and restricted range of motion, with physical examination also showing swelling, redness, and warmth of the joint. While the patient's symptoms are very similar to septic arthritis, the bloody synovial fluid and absence of fever rule out this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A decreased platelet count (thrombocytopenia) can be a symptom of numerous conditions. The most common causes include impaired platelet production (e.g., due to bone marrow failure, infections, malignancy) and increased platelet turnover (e.g., disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura). Symptoms of thrombocytopenia include easy bruising, mucosal bleeding, and petechiae if the platelet count drops below ∼ 30,000/mm3. Although severe thrombocytopenia can lead to hemarthrosis, it is unlikely to be the initial symptom in a previously healthy child.
Image Description:

(1) Tissue injury results in the release of von Willebrand Factor (vWF) from Weibel Palade bodies (WPB) in endothelium and α-granules in platelets. VWF subsequently binds to exposed collagen at the site of injury. Vasoconstriction (not shown here) occurs through both a neural stimulation reflex and a release of endothelin from damaged endothelial cells.

(2) Platelets bind to exposed vWF at the site of injury and undergo a conformational change.

(3) Activated platelets release a combination of factors, including adenosine diphosphate (ADP), calcium ions (Ca2+), and platelet-activating factor (PAF). ADP binds to P2Y12 receptors on platelets, inducing a translocation of GpIIb/IIIa receptors to the cell surface. These receptors are promoted by Ca2+ ions.

(4) The expression of GpIIb/IIIa receptors allows activated platelets to crosslink with fibrinogen as an intermediary. The action of PAF along with thromboxane A2 (TXA2) further promotes platelet aggregation.

Platelet plugs are reinforced with fibrin during secondary hemostasis.

C) CORRECT:

Prolonged partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is a diagnostic feature of hemophilia A, an X-linked recessive disease characterized by deficient factor VIII. A principal clinical feature is hemorrhage into a single weight-bearing joint, which can occur spontaneously or following minimal trauma. Repeated hemarthrosis can lead to joint destruction over time. Further hemorrhages may occur in the CNS, in gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts, and from mucous membranes. Blood tests also show normal prothrombin time and normal platelet count. The diagnosis is confirmed through mixing studies and quantitative assessment of factor VIII activity levels.

D) INCORRECT:

An elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate in a child with joint pain is suggestive of several underlying conditions, including juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) and septic arthritis. Although the findings of the patient's physical examination may be seen in both conditions, JIA usually affects several joints and also manifests with extra-articular symptoms (e.g., anterior uveitis), while septic arthritis typically also presents with fever. Moreover, neither condition is associated with hemarthrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated antinuclear antibody levels in a child with joint pain and reduced range of motion are suggestive of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). Further possible features include early morning stiffness, chronic anterior uveitis, and systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, generalized lymphadenopathy). The synovial fluid is typically yellow and cloudy. Since JIA usually affects several joints, is present for ≥ 6 weeks, and hemarthrosis does not occur, this diagnosis can be ruled out.
Image Description:

Commonly involved joints for each subtype are highlighted in red.

Also illustrated in systemic JIA are pyrexia, and the extra-articular manifestations of lymphadenopathy, serositis (pleuritis, peritonitis, and/or pericarditis), and hepatosplenomegaly

Note: Anterior uveitis in psoriatic JIA is commonly bilateral and chronic, while in enthesitis-related JIA it more commonly manifests as unilateral flare-ups.

F) INCORRECT:

A sunburst appearance on x-ray is a diagnostic feature of osteosarcoma, a malignant tumor that primarily affects the distal femur and proximal tibia. It typically occurs in older children (rarely < 5 years) and adolescents, who usually have a history of several weeks to months of pain in the affected limb, especially with activity. Depending on the size of the tumor, swelling may be present. Considering the patient's age, acute onset of symptoms, and joint swelling secondary to hemarthrosis, osteosarcoma can be ruled out.

G) INCORRECT:

A prolonged prothrombin time indicates a disorder of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, specifically of fibrin formation. Causes include vitamin K deficiency, reduced or impaired production of coagulation factors (e.g., liver disease), and treatment with warfarin. Since spontaneous hemarthrosis is indicative of advanced liver disease or severe vitamin K deficiency, it is unlikely to be the first presenting symptom in a previously healthy child.
questions.hint: Factor VIII activity levels should be evaluated in a 3-year-old patient with hemarthrosis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 6-month history of recurrent spontaneous nosebleeds. He states that he is able to stop the bleeding within 10 minutes by lightly pinching his nose at the nostrils. He has no history of serious illness except for prolonged bleeding following wisdom teeth extraction 2 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the nose shows no abnormalities. There are several bruises on the lower extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15 g/dL


Leukocyte count
6000/mm3



Platelet count
220,000/mm3



Bleeding time

9 minutes (N = 2–7)


Prothrombin time
13 sec


Partial thromboplastin time
50 sec


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bernard-Soulier Syndrome (BSS) is an autosomal recessive disorder that leads to platelet dysfunction. BSS is often asymptomatic but can manifest with epistaxis, easy bruising, prolonged bleeding time, and either a low or normal platelet count. However, BSS does not cause prolonged PTT.

B) INCORRECT:

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a consumption coagulopathy that most commonly occurs due to sepsis, trauma, or malignancy. DIC has a variable manifestation but usually occurs acutely rather than chronically. Also, in addition to prolonged bleeding time and PTT, laboratory results would show low platelets and prolonged PT.

C) INCORRECT:

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an x-linked immunodeficiency that causes T-cell dysfunction. Manifestations of the disease typically involve immunologic findings, such as eczema, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, and recurrent opportunistic infections, none of which are seen in this patient. WAS can manifest with a prolonged bleeding time, but a low platelet count would also be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemophilia A, an x-linked recessive disease with factor VIII deficiency manifests with recurrent epistaxis, episodes of heavy bleeding following medical procedures, bruises, and prolonged PTT. However, bleeding time would be normal since platelets are unaffected.

E) INCORRECT:

Factor X deficiency is a rare, autosomal recessive disease or can also be acquired from liver disease or vitamin K deficiency. This condition can also manifest with recurrent epistaxis and easy bruising. However, laboratory results would show prolonged PT and PTT due to factor X's involvement in the common pathway of the coagulation cascade. Additionally, bleeding time would be normal since platelets are unaffected.

F) INCORRECT:

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive disorder that prevents platelet aggregation. This condition typically manifests with mucosal bleeding (e.g. epistaxis). While a prolonged bleeding time is expected, further laboratory parameters are typically normal in Glanzmann thrombasthenia. This patient also has a prolonged PTT, making a different diagnosis more likely.

G) CORRECT:

Von Willebrand disease occurs when there is a deficiency or defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF). The deficiency hinders the ability of platelets to adhere to subendothelial collagen and inhibits platelet activation, which leads to a prolonged bleeding time. PT and PTT are generally in normal ranges in patients with this condition because the clotting factors are unaffected. However, factor VIII is bound to vWF in the blood to prevent rapid breakdown. Thus, half of the patients with vWD can also present with mildly prolonged PTT, as seen in this patient.

Desmopressin is the treatment of choice for vWD types 1 and 2 because it stimulates vWF release from endothelial cells. Desmopressin is not an effective treatment in type 3 because of the complete absence of vWF.
Image Description:

Red indicators link syndromes with their associated defective or absent molecules, according to which phase of primary hemostasis is affected (i.e., adhesion or aggregation)
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent epistaxis, a previous episode of heavy bleeding following tooth extraction, and multiple bruises. His laboratory studies show prolonged bleeding time despite normal platelet count and prolonged PTT. These features are consistent with the most common congenital hemostatic disorder.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of several episodes of painless bloody urine over the past 6 months. The episodes are not related to physical activity. He has had frequent nosebleeds since early childhood and an episode of heavy bleeding after a tooth extraction one year ago. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. He drinks one to two beers on social occasions. He appears pale. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows several small hematomas in different stages of healing over his arms and legs. Examination of the extremities shows decreased passive range of motion with crepitus in both ankles. His abdomen is soft and nontender. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.5 mg/dL


Leukocyte count
5000/mm3



Platelet count
240,000/mm3



Bleeding time
5 minutes (N = 2–7)



Prothrombin time
14 seconds


Partial thromboplastin time
68 seconds


Urine



RBC
30–40/hpf


RBC casts
negative


WBC
none


Protein
negative


An x-ray of the pelvis shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Evasive behavior when asked about the hematomas
History of spontaneous hematomas in paternal grandmother
Palpable spleen below the left costal margin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple hematomas and/or ecchymoses at various stages of healing, as seen in this patient, are concerning for abuse. However, his history of spontaneous bleeding and abnormal lab findings makes another diagnosis a more likely cause of his hematomas.

B) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous hematomas are characteristic of severe hemophilia, which this patient has evidence for. However, hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder, meaning that he must have inherited the trait from his carrier mother. The presence of symptoms in a paternal relative is very unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

While the differential for petechiae is broad, the presence of petechiae in the oropharynx usually suggests thrombocytopenia, trauma, or infection. Petechiae would not be expected in this patient with normal vital signs and normal platelet count.

D) INCORRECT:

A palpable spleen suggests splenomegaly, the differential diagnoses of which include sequestration of RBCs, extramedullary hematopoiesis, trauma, neoplasm, and portal hypertension. This patient's coagulopathy suggests an underlying hematologic abnormality, but he lacks other findings to support a process that might have caused splenomegaly.

E) CORRECT:

Intraarticular iron deposition from hemarthrosis can lead to hemophilic arthropathy, an important cause of disability in patients with hemophilia. The iron deposition causes increased synovial inflammation and recurrent synovitis, eventually leading to erosion and loss of cartilage, joint-space narrowing, and permanent joint destruction. Hemophilic arthropathy typically presents in early adolescence and most commonly affects the ankles, knees, and elbows. Although there are no obvious signs of hemarthrosis, there is evidence of hemophilia and decreased range of motion in his ankles that suggests hemophilic arthropathy.

F) INCORRECT:

Hemosiderin-laden alveolar macrophages are characteristic bronchoscopy findings in diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). While this patient’s coagulopathy puts him at risk of developing DAH, he has no symptoms (hemoptysis, cough, fever) to suggest DAH.
questions.hint: This patient presents with hematuria, hematomas, and a history of heavy bleeding after a tooth extraction, all of which suggest an inherited bleeding disorder. The prolonged partial thromboplastin time is consistent with hemophilia.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of excessive bleeding after undergoing a dental procedure. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 195,000/mm3, a partial thromboplastin time of 44 sec, and a prothrombin time of 12 sec. A one-stage clotting assay shows a decreased factor VIII. Therapy with a drug that acts on endothelial cells is initiated. This drug is most likely to result in which of the following?

choices.text: Decreased cAMP in renal tubular cells
Increased tubular fluid osmolarity in the loop of Henle
Decreased binding of angiotensin II to AT1 receptor
Increased permeability to urea in the collecting duct

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased cAMP in renal tubular cells would be observed in patients who were given vasopressin (receptor) antagonists, e.g., conivaptan. Desmopressin, however, increases cAMP via interaction with V2-receptors and subsequent activation of adenylyl cyclase. The effects of high cAMP concentrations include the integration of aquaporins into the plasma membrane of collecting duct cells and an increase in water reabsorption.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased tubular fluid osmolarity in the loop of Henle would be seen in patients who have received mannitol, which is freely filtered by the kidneys without undergoing reabsorption and thereby creates a strong osmotic gradient with subsequent diuresis. Mannitol is commonly used in patients with elevated intracranial pressure or acute prerenal failure. In contrast, the concentrating effect of desmopressin occurs only in the collecting ducts, thus leaving the osmolarity in the loop of Henle.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased binding of angiotensin II to AT1 receptors would be observed in a patient taking angiotensin receptor blockers, not desmopressin. ARBs would be of no use in this patient, as they promote diuresis through vasodilation and natriuresis and have no role in the treatment of hemophilia.

D) CORRECT:

Increased permeability to urea in the collecting duct is found in patients who are treated with vasopressin analogs. This group of drugs binds to V2-receptors, triggering a cascade of intracellular reactions that ultimately result in increased numbers of UT-A1 proteins in the apical plasma membrane. UT-A1 facilitates urea reabsorption in the inner medullary collecting duct.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased bleeding time would not be seen in this patient who is receiving desmopressin, which shortens aPTT and bleeding time. These blood parameter changes are mediated by a release of factor VIII and vWF through cAMP-mediated cell-signaling.
questions.hint: This boy's excessive bleeding after a dental procedure and an increased aPTT raise suspicion for hemophilia A, which is very likely considering his deficient factor VIII levels. Desmopressin, a synthetic analog of vasopressin, is the medical treatment of choice for mild hemophilia.

questions.text:
A previously healthy, 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with persistent bleeding from his gums after an elective removal of an impacted tooth. Multiple gauze packs were applied with minimal effect. He has a history of easy bruising. His family history is unremarkable except for a maternal uncle who had a history of easy bruising and joint swelling. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
36%


Platelet count
170,000/mm3


Prothrombin time
13 sec


Partial thromboplastin time
65 sec


Bleeding time

5 min (N = 2–7)



Peripheral blood smear shows normal-sized platelets. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain types of von Willebrand disease can present with findings similar to those seen in this patient (mucosal bleeding, normal or ↑ PTT). However, von Willebrand disease also causes increased bleeding time, and it is autosomal dominant, meaning that one of the patient's parents would likely have a history of bleeding diathesis as well.

B) INCORRECT:

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an inherited disorder causing excessive bleeding, which often presents with mucosal bleeding or excessive postprocedural bleeding. However, Glanzmann thrombasthenia presents with normal PTT and platelet count, ↑ bleeding time, and isolated platelets without clumping on peripheral smear, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, Glanzmann thrombasthenia is usually diagnosed in infancy or early childhood.

C) CORRECT:

Excessive bleeding in an otherwise healthy young male who easily bruises, with a probable family history of the disease in a maternal uncle and isolated PTT elevation is highly suspicious for hemophilia. Because hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder, it affects males almost exclusively, and ⅔ of patients have a positive family history in a maternal male relative. The history of easy bruising and joint swelling (likely hemarthrosis) in his maternal uncle is characteristic of hemophilia. Inherited hemophilias cause isolated factor VIII, IX, or XI deficiency (all part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway), presenting with isolated PTT (which measures intrinsic pathway function) elevation on lab workup.

Because of his highly suggestive family history, the next best step for this patient is to acquire clotting factor activity levels to confirm the diagnosis. For patients with less suggestive histories, a mixing study would be the most appropriate next step. Hemophilia A is more common than hemophilia B; hemophilia C is the rarest type of hemophilia.

D) INCORRECT:

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is caused by sepsis, trauma, or shock, and results in a consumptive coagulopathy. While DIC causes excessive bleeding and ↑ PTT, this patient's vital signs are normal, he appears well, and he has no history of trauma; DIC is therefore unlikely based on history alone. Additionally, DIC causes ↑ PT, ↑ bleeding time, ↑ fibrin degradation products, ↓ platelets, ↓ plasma fibrinogen, and schistocytes on blood smear, none of which are seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenia can cause mucosal bleeding, which is seen in this patient. However, it is also associated with a low platelet count, petechiae, and sometimes prolonged bleeding time, none of which are present in this patient. Finally, immune thrombocytopenia more frequently affects children and women of childbearing age, rather than teenage boys.

F) INCORRECT:

Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an inherited disorder causing excessive bleeding that can present with similar symptoms. However, patients with Bernard-Soulier syndrome have a normal PTT,↑ bleeding time, and giant platelets on peripheral smear, none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after the removal of a tooth. During the procedure, he had prolonged bleeding that did not resolve with pressure and gauze packing and eventually required suture placement. His older brother had a similar episode a year ago, but his parents and two sisters have never had problems with prolonged bleeding. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Genetic analysis confirms an X-linked recessive disorder. Which of the following is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hemophilias are hereditary disorders of secondary hemostasis that can manifest with prolonged bleeding after surgery (e.g., tooth extraction), hemarthrosis, and hematomas. Depending on the severity of clotting factor deficiency, bleeding may occur spontaneously or in response to trauma. Hemophilia A, which is caused by deficiency of factor VIII, and hemophilia B, which is caused by deficiency of factor IX, both follow an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance. Since hemophilia A (∼ 80% of cases) is much more common than hemophilia B (∼ 20% of cases), this patient most likely has hemophilia A.

Treatment of hemophilia A includes desmopressin, or in severe cases, substitution of factor VIII. Repeated hemarthrosis can eventually lead to joint destruction, a serious long-term complication of hemophilia.

B) INCORRECT:

Von Willebrand factor deficiency is the underlying cause of von Willebrand disease, which can also manifest with an episode of heavy bleeding following tooth extraction. Von Willebrand disease follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. This patient, however, has an X-linked recessive disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Factor XI deficiency is consistent with hemophilia C, which can also manifest with an episode of heavy bleeding following tooth extraction. Hemophilia C follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. This patient, however, has an X-linked recessive disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Protein C deficiency is a rare disorder of the coagulation system that results in overactivity of factor V and factor VIII. This condition would result in a state of hypercoagulability, which would increase the risk of thrombotic events, but not bleeding. Moreover, protein C deficiency follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. This patient, however, has an X-linked recessive disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency, which leads to a deficiency of the coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, can also manifest with an episode of heavy bleeding following tooth extraction. However, vitamin K deficiency is usually due to intake of a vitamin K antagonist (e.g., warfarin), malabsorption syndrome, depletion of gut flora (e.g., following antibiotic administration), or impaired hepatic production (e.g., liver cirrhosis), none of which is described here. Hereditary combined vitamin K-dependent clotting factor deficiency (VKCFD) is a rare bleeding disorder that follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. This patient, however, has an X-linked recessive disorder.

F) INCORRECT:

Factor IX deficiency is consistent with hemophilia B, which can also manifest with an episode of heavy bleeding following tooth extraction. Hemophilia B also follows an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance. However, hemophilia B (∼ 20% of cases) is much rarer than hemophilia A (∼ 80%), making hemophilia A a more likely diagnosis in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has hemophilia A.

questions.text: A previously healthy 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of pain and swelling of his left knee joint. He has not had any trauma to the knee. His family history is unremarkable except for a bleeding disorder in his maternal uncle. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F). The left knee is erythematous, swollen, and tender; range of motion is limited. No other joints are affected. An x-ray of the knee shows an effusion but no structural abnormalities of the joint. Arthrocentesis is conducted. The synovial fluid is bloody. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated antinuclear antibody levels in a child with joint pain and reduced range of motion are suggestive of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). Further possible features include early morning stiffness, chronic anterior uveitis, and systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, generalized lymphadenopathy). The synovial fluid is typically yellow and cloudy. Since JIA usually affects several joints, is present for ≥ 6 weeks, and hemarthrosis does not occur, this diagnosis can be ruled out.
Image Description:

Commonly involved joints for each subtype are highlighted in red.

Also illustrated in systemic JIA are pyrexia, and the extra-articular manifestations of lymphadenopathy, serositis (pleuritis, peritonitis, and/or pericarditis), and hepatosplenomegaly

Note: Anterior uveitis in psoriatic JIA is commonly bilateral and chronic, while in enthesitis-related JIA it more commonly manifests as unilateral flare-ups.

B) INCORRECT:

A decreased platelet count (thrombocytopenia) can be a symptom of numerous conditions. The most common causes include impaired platelet production (e.g., due to bone marrow failure, infections, malignancy) and increased platelet turnover (e.g., disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura). Symptoms of thrombocytopenia include easy bruising, mucosal bleeding, and petechiae if the platelet count drops below ∼ 30,000/mm3. Although severe thrombocytopenia can lead to hemarthrosis, it is unlikely to be the initial symptom in a previously healthy child.
Image Description:

(1) Tissue injury results in the release of von Willebrand Factor (vWF) from Weibel Palade bodies (WPB) in endothelium and α-granules in platelets. VWF subsequently binds to exposed collagen at the site of injury. Vasoconstriction (not shown here) occurs through both a neural stimulation reflex and a release of endothelin from damaged endothelial cells.

(2) Platelets bind to exposed vWF at the site of injury and undergo a conformational change.

(3) Activated platelets release a combination of factors, including adenosine diphosphate (ADP), calcium ions (Ca2+), and platelet-activating factor (PAF). ADP binds to P2Y12 receptors on platelets, inducing a translocation of GpIIb/IIIa receptors to the cell surface. These receptors are promoted by Ca2+ ions.

(4) The expression of GpIIb/IIIa receptors allows activated platelets to crosslink with fibrinogen as an intermediary. The action of PAF along with thromboxane A2 (TXA2) further promotes platelet aggregation.

Platelet plugs are reinforced with fibrin during secondary hemostasis.

C) INCORRECT:

A prolonged prothrombin time indicates a disorder of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, specifically of fibrin formation. Causes include vitamin K deficiency, reduced or impaired production of coagulation factors (e.g., liver disease), and treatment with warfarin. Since spontaneous hemarthrosis is indicative of advanced liver disease or severe vitamin K deficiency, it is unlikely to be the first presenting symptom in a previously healthy child.

D) INCORRECT:

An elevated ESR in a child with joint pain is suggestive of several underlying conditions, including juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) and septic arthritis. Although the findings of the patient's physical examination may be seen in both conditions, JIA usually affects several joints and also manifests with extra-articular symptoms (e.g., anterior uveitis), while septic arthritis typically also presents with fever. Moreover, neither condition is associated with hemarthrosis.

E) CORRECT:

Prolonged partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is a diagnostic feature of hemophilia A, an X-linked recessive disease characterized by defective factor VIII. A principal clinical feature is hemorrhage into a single weight-bearing joint, which can occur spontaneously or following minimal trauma. Repeated hemarthrosis can lead to joint destruction over time. Further hemorrhages may occur in the CNS, in gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts, and from mucous membranes. Blood tests show a prolonged aPTT, normal prothrombin time, and normal platelet count. The diagnosis is confirmed through mixing studies and quantitative assessment of factor VIII activity levels.

A prolonged aPTT indicates a disorder of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. Underlying conditions include hemophilia, von Willebrand disease (vWD), and treatment with heparin.

F) INCORRECT:

Leukocytosis and a yellowish-green appearance of synovial fluid are diagnostic features of septic arthritis, a bacterial infection of the joint space. The infection presents with a triad of fever, joint pain, and restricted range of motion, with physical examination also showing swelling, redness, and warmth of the joint. While the patient's symptoms are very similar to septic arthritis, the bloody synovial fluid and absence of fever rule out this diagnosis.
questions.hint: Factor VIII activity levels should be evaluated in a 4-year-old patient with hemarthrosis.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-day history of joint swelling and pain in his left elbow. He has not had any trauma. His mother reports that he has also had recurrent episodes of nosebleeds over the past 3 months. He has no personal history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is at the 70th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. His left elbow is erythematous, swollen, and tender to palpation; range of motion is limited due to pain. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the left upper extremity. Nasal examination shows no abnormalities. There are multiple bruises over both shins. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.5 mg/dL


Leukocyte count
7500/mm3



Platelet count

200,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
15 seconds (INR = 1.1)


Partial thromboplastin time
62 seconds


Bleeding time

5 minutes (N = 2–7)


A peripheral blood smear shows normal-sized platelets. Which of the following is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gp IIb/IIIa deficiency causes Glanzmann thrombasthenia, an inherited bleeding disorder that prevents platelet aggregation while platelet count remains normal. This condition is characterized by a prolonged bleeding time (due to dysfunctional platelet aggregation) and not only PT but also PTT would be normal because clotting factors are unaffected. Glanzmann thrombasthenia is usually diagnosed in infancy or early childhood, and spontaneous hemarthrosis (as suggested by this patient's swollen elbow) is not a common manifestation.

B) INCORRECT:

Factor XI deficiency is seen in hemophilia C, the rarest form of hemophilia (approx. 1/100,000 individuals in the US). This patient's isolated PTT elevation is consistent with hemophilia C. However, hemophilia C does not typically manifest with spontaneous or deep tissue bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis), which this patient with a swollen elbow most likely has. Patients with hemophilia C present with multiple bruises and bleeding, typically in the setting of surgery or trauma. In addition, hemophilia C has an increased frequency in individuals of Ashkenazi and Iraqi Jewish ancestry.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency results in decreased serum levels of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, which can lead to signs of bleeding diathesis (e.g., recurrent epistaxis, multiple bruises, spontaneous hemarthrosis). Normal platelet count, normal thrombocyte morphology, and a normal bleeding time are consistent with this condition. However, in vitamin K deficiency, all pathways of coagulation are affected, so not only PTT but also PT is typically prolonged. In addition, vitamin K deficiency is usually seen in newborns or due to intake of a vitamin K antagonist (e.g., warfarin), malabsorption syndrome, depletion of gut flora (e.g., following antibiotic administration), or impaired hepatic production (e.g., liver cirrhosis).

D) CORRECT:

Recurrent episodes of epistaxis, multiple bruises, and spontaneous hemarthrosis (indicated here by the swollen elbow) raise suspicion for hemophilia. Hemophilias A, B, and C (inherited hemophilias) are associated with a deficiency in factor VIII, IX, and XI, respectively. Because they affect the intrinsic coagulation pathway, all of these deficiencies manifest with elevated PTT and normal PT. Both hemophilia A and B follow an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance and affect male individuals almost exclusively. Hemophilia A is the most common form (∼ 80% of cases) and is classically associated with deep tissue bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis), meaning that factor VIII deficiency is most likely in this patient.

A mixing study is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis. In patients with hemophilia, PTT will be corrected to normal when the patient's plasma is mixed with normal plasma in a 1:1 ratio.

E) INCORRECT:

Von Willebrand factor (vWF) deficiency causes von Willebrand disease (vWD), a common inherited bleeding disorder that impairs platelet function while platelet count remains normal. Severe cases, such as type 3 vWD, may manifest with signs of bleeding similar to those seen in this patient (e.g., recurrent epistaxis, ecchymoses, sometimes hemarthrosis). vWF carries and stabilizes coagulation factor VIII, so significantly reduced vWF levels may result in prolonged PTT, while PT levels remain normal because only the intrinsic pathway of coagulation is affected. However, dysfunctional platelet adherence and activation characteristically result in a prolonged bleeding time. Moreover, vWD is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, so a family history for bleeding diathesis would be expected as well.

F) INCORRECT:

Gp Ib/IX/V deficiency causes Bernard-Soulier syndrome, an inherited bleeding disorder that inhibits platelet adhesion. This condition is characterized by a prolonged bleeding time, thrombocytopenia, and giant platelets on a peripheral blood smear. Furthermore, PTT would be normal because clotting factors are unaffected. Finally, deep tissue bleeding, such as spontaneous hemarthrosis (as suggested by this patient's swollen elbow), is not a common manifestation of Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

G) INCORRECT:

ADAMTS13 deficiency causes thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), a bleeding disorder due to decreased cleavage of von Willebrand factor (vWF) and subsequent microthrombi formation. Characteristic manifestations of this condition include thrombocytopenia, fever, hemolytic anemia, renal insufficiency, and neurologic impairment (e.g., altered mental status). Additionally, patients usually present with petechiae, purpura, or prolonged bleeding after cuts, rather than hemarthrosis (as suggested by this patient's swollen elbow). Finally, spontaneous bleeding usually occurs only at platelet counts < 20,000/mm3, and a blood smear typically shows schistocytes.
questions.hint: A very similar bleeding disorder was referred to as "the royal disease" during the 19th and 20th centuries; Queen Victoria of Britain passed the disease to various royal houses across Europe. Those royals who had manifestations of this disease were almost exclusively male descendants (e.g., Lord Leopold Mountbatten), whereas female descendants were mostly only carriers.

questions.text:
A 4-week-old adopted male infant experiences bleeding during circumcision that is difficult to control. He was born at term via spontaneous vaginal delivery without any complications, had an unremarkable physical examination at the time, and received erythromycin and vitamin K shortly after birth.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
14,300
5000–19,500


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
17.0
10.0–18.0


Hematocrit (%)
51.0
31.0–55.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
303,000
150,000–450,000


Prothrombin time (sec)
14.0
10.0–14.4


Partial thromboplastin time (sec)
77.0
25.0–49.2


A mixing study shows normalization of the partial thromboplastin time.
Which one of the following tests is the most appropriate next step in evaluation for this patient?

choices.text: Factor VIII and IX activity levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombin time may be prolonged or normal when a blood sample is contaminated with heparin or a factor inhibitor is present, but it is not a definitive test. Furthermore, this patient has no evidence of heparin in the blood.

B) INCORRECT:

Factor Xa levels are used to monitor plasma heparin and low-molecular-weight heparin levels when those agents are being used therapeutically. There is no record of this patient receiving heparin, and the normalized mixing study confirms this.

C) INCORRECT:

If the patient is found to have factor VIII deficiency, von Willebrand factor antigen testing should be performed to exclude von Willebrand disease.

D) CORRECT:

Bleeding that is difficult to control after circumcision may be a manifestation of hemophilia and should prompt urgent evaluation. This patient’s initial laboratory tests showed a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT), which may be a sign of hemophilia but could also be due to the presence of heparin or a factor inhibitor in the blood. A mixing study was appropriately obtained first, to rule out heparin contamination and factor inhibitors. In a mixing test, the patient’s plasma and normal pooled plasma are combined in a 1:1 ratio, and the PTT is repeated. It remains prolonged in the presence of heparin or an inhibitor but approaches normal in a patient with hemophilia. This patient’s mixing study revealed a correction, consistent with factor deficiency, so the most appropriate next step is to measure factor VIII and IX levels. A factor VIII assay is necessary for the diagnosis of hemophilia A, and a factor IX assay is necessary for the diagnosis of hemophilia B.

Key learning point: Factor VIII and IX deficiencies are associated with a laboratory finding of prolonged partial thromboplastin time.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K is administered to infants to reduce the risk for vitamin K-deficient bleeding. When such bleeding is suspected, the test of choice is measurement of PIVKA-III (proteins induced in vitamin K absence) levels, not vitamin K levels. Vitamin K-deficient bleeding is a much less likely diagnosis than hemophilia in this patient who received prophylactic vitamin K.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old boy is hospitalized for refusal to bear weight and swelling of his right knee. His parents report that he has been standing and cruising for the past 6 weeks, but today he suddenly refused to stand and cried when attempting to put weight on his right leg. His parents do not recall any specific trauma, although he does fall sometimes. He had an upper respiratory infection last week but is otherwise healthy. He was born at term via uncomplicated repeat cesarean section, and he has had no previous hospitalizations or surgeries.
His temperature is 36.4°C, his heart rate is 178 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 63 breaths per minute. On examination, his right knee is swollen and somewhat warm to the touch without erythema. The right knee has restricted range of motion secondary to both pain and swelling.
A radiograph of the right knee reveals soft-tissue edema without fracture.
Initial laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
16,700
6000–17,500


Neutrophils (%)
60
25–49


Lymphocytes (%)
35
60–67


Monocytes (%)
5
4–11


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.9
10.5–13.5


Hematocrit (%)
30
33.0–39.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
173,000
150,000–450,000


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
2
0–5


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hour)
5
0–10


Prothrombin time (sec)
13.0
11.0–14.0


Partial thromboplastin time (sec)
65.5
22.0–35.0


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis in infants usually manifests with signs of systemic infection and septicemia. Cellulitis is often present, and features of joint involvement may be subtle. Septic arthritis is unlikely in this patient, who is afebrile and whose C-reactive protein level, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and leukocyte count are all normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Although failure to bear weight in a nonambulatory child should raise concern for nonaccidental trauma, this patient’s overall clinical picture — an abnormal PTT and localized symptoms without evidence of fracture — do not suggest abuse.

C) INCORRECT:

Ligament tears manifest with a swollen joint but are traumatic injuries that are more common in older children who can run. In addition, one would not expect abnormal laboratory findings with a ligament tear.

D) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis may manifest with joint pain, swelling, and warmth, usually after bacterial gastroenteritis or a streptococcal infection. It is not associated with an elevated PTT.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s laboratory findings are significant for a normal prothrombin time and an elevated partial thromboplastin time (PTT), consistent with hemophilia. The pain and swelling in his right knee is likely due to hemarthrosis, a common finding in hemophilia that is often described on plain-film radiographs as nonspecific soft-tissue swelling. Most patients with severe hemophilia show symptoms of the disorder in the first year of life. During the newborn period, common manifestations include cephalohematoma, intracranial hemorrhage, and bleeding after circumcision. As the child begins learning to walk, bruising and joint bleeds are more common.

Key learning point: Joint pain and swelling in a child with an elevated partial thromboplastin time is most consistent with a diagnosis of hemophilia.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 13 months
Sex Assigned at Birth: M
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My son has a large bruise on his forehead from falling.”
History of Present Illness:


fell off the couch onto the hardwood floor 2 hours ago while trying to climb onto it 
gradually expanding swelling on the left forehead


Past Medical History:

has bruised easily since birth; was diagnosed with hemophilia B after multiple episodes of oral mucosal bleeding and epistaxis 4 months ago
uncomplicated pregnancy; cesarean delivery due to breech position

Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

mother and father: alive with no chronic conditions
sister: no chronic conditions
maternal uncle: diagnosed with hemophilia at 2 years of age

Psychosocial History:

lives with parents and older sister
attends daycare 3 days a week

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.9°C (98.4°F)
110/min
32/min
95/60 mm Hg
98% on RA
79 cm (2 ft 7 in)75th %ile
9.6 kg (21 lb 3 oz)25th %ile
-



Appearance: awake and alert
HEENT: 6-cm hematoma on the left forehead; no open wound; PEERLA; ocular movements are intact; oral mucosa pink and moist
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: soft and nontender; normoactive bowel sounds; liver and spleen cannot be palpated
Extremities: no joint swelling; normal range of motion
Neurologic: cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal deficits


Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a patient with hemophilia, clotting factors should be administered after head trauma to prevent intracranial hemorrhage. Neuroimaging to exclude intracranial hemorrhage is indicated following any head injury in a patient with hemophilia, but replacement of clotting factors should not be delayed for diagnostic studies. Administration of factor IX concentrate is necessary for patients with hemophilia B. Patients with hemophilia A and C should receive factor VIII and factor XI respectively. Because bleeding due to head trauma can be delayed, the patient's family should be advised on signs of late bleeding. In patients with severe hemophilia, prophylactic replacement of clotting factors can reduce the risk of spontaneous bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage, and long-term complications, such as chronic arthropathy from recurrent joint bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

In individuals with hemophilia, head trauma is a medical emergency that requires immediate pharmacotherapy before diagnostic workup. Delaying or withholding pharmacotherapy significantly increases the risk of severe complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Emicizumab is a recombinant humanized bispecific monoclonal antibody that mimics the activity of factor VIIIa. While emicizumab is an option for prophylactic treatment in hemophilia A, it is not effective for treating acute bleeding or for individuals with hemophilia B, which is a factor IX deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin, a synthetic analog of vasopressin without vasoconstrictive properties, stimulates the endogenous release of factor VIII and can be used in mild bleeding or small surgical interventions for individuals with mild hemophilia A. Desmopressin is ineffective for acute bleeding in individuals with hemophilia B, which is a factor IX deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Cryoprecipitate contains fibrinogen, factor VIII, factor XIII, von Willebrand factor, and fibronectin. Although purified plasma products are preferred to treat acute bleeding, alternatives may be used in resource-limited settings. Fresh frozen plasma can be administered to patients with hemophilia A, B, and C, and cryoprecipitate to those with hemophilia A. Cryoprecipitate does not contain factor IX, which is deficient in hemophilia B.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 3-day history of joint swelling and pain in his left elbow. He has not had any trauma. His mother reports that he has also had recurrent episodes of nosebleeds over the past 3 months. Vital signs are within normal limits. His left elbow is erythematous, swollen, and tender to palpation; range of motion is limited due to pain. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the left upper extremity. Nasal examination shows no abnormalities. There are multiple bruises over both shins. Laboratory studies show:


Platelet count

200,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
14 seconds


Partial thromboplastin time
62 seconds


Bleeding time

5 minutes (N = 2–7)


A peripheral blood smear shows normal-sized platelets. Which of the following is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Factor XI deficiency is seen in hemophilia C, the rarest form of hemophilia (approx. 1/100,000 individuals in the US). This patient's isolated PTT elevation is consistent with hemophilia C. However, hemophilia C does not typically manifest with spontaneous or deep tissue bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis), which this patient with a swollen elbow most likely has. Patients with hemophilia C present with multiple bruises and bleeding, typically in the setting of surgery or trauma. In addition, hemophilia C has an increased frequency in individuals of Ashkenazi and Iraqi Jewish ancestry.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency results in decreased serum levels of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, which can lead to signs of bleeding diathesis (e.g., recurrent epistaxis, multiple bruises, spontaneous hemarthrosis). Normal platelet count, normal thrombocyte morphology, and a normal bleeding time are consistent with this condition. However, in vitamin K deficiency, all pathways of coagulation are affected, so not only PTT but also PT is typically prolonged. In addition, vitamin K deficiency is usually seen in newborns or due to intake of a vitamin K antagonist (e.g., warfarin), malabsorption syndrome, depletion of gut flora (e.g., following antibiotic administration), or impaired hepatic production (e.g., liver cirrhosis).

C) CORRECT:

Recurrent episodes of epistaxis, multiple bruises, and spontaneous hemarthrosis (indicated here by the swollen elbow) raise suspicion for hemophilia. Hemophilias A, B, and C (inherited hemophilias) are associated with a deficiency in factor VIII, IX, and XI, respectively. Because they affect the intrinsic coagulation pathway, all of these deficiencies manifest with elevated PTT and normal PT. Both hemophilia A and B follow an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance and affect male individuals almost exclusively. Hemophilia A is the most common form (∼ 80% of cases) and is classically associated with deep tissue bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis), meaning that factor VIII deficiency is most likely in this patient.

A mixing study is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis. In patients with hemophilia, PTT will be corrected to normal when the patient's plasma is mixed with normal plasma in a 1:1 ratio.

Key learning point: Hemophilia A is caused by a deficiency of factor VIII and presents with deep tissue bleeding, such as hemarthrosis, and an isolated prolonged PTT.

D) INCORRECT:

Von Willebrand factor (vWF) deficiency causes von Willebrand disease (vWD), a common inherited bleeding disorder that impairs platelet function while platelet count remains normal. Severe cases, such as type 3 vWD, may manifest with signs of bleeding similar to those seen in this patient (e.g., recurrent epistaxis, ecchymoses, sometimes hemarthrosis). vWF carries and stabilizes coagulation factor VIII, so significantly reduced vWF levels may result in prolonged PTT, while PT levels remain normal because only the intrinsic pathway of coagulation is affected. However, dysfunctional platelet adherence and activation characteristically result in a prolonged bleeding time. Moreover, vWD is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, so a family history for bleeding diathesis would be expected as well.

E) INCORRECT:

ADAMTS13 deficiency causes thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), a bleeding disorder due to decreased cleavage of von Willebrand factor (vWF) and subsequent microthrombi formation. Characteristic manifestations of this condition include thrombocytopenia, fever, hemolytic anemia, renal insufficiency, and neurologic impairment (e.g., altered mental status). Additionally, patients usually present with petechiae, purpura, or prolonged bleeding after cuts, rather than hemarthrosis (as suggested by this patient's swollen elbow). Finally, spontaneous bleeding usually occurs only at platelet counts < 20,000/mm3, and a blood smear typically shows schistocytes.
questions.hint: A very similar bleeding disorder was referred to as "the royal disease" during the 19th and 20th centuries; Queen Victoria of Britain passed the disease to various royal houses across Europe. Those royals who had manifestations of this disease were almost exclusively male descendants (e.g., Lord Leopold Mountbatten), whereas female descendants were mostly only carriers.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents for the evaluation of a 6-month history of recurrent spontaneous nosebleeds. He states that he is able to stop the bleeding within 10 minutes by lightly pinching his nose at the nostrils. He has no history of serious illness except for prolonged bleeding following wisdom teeth extraction 2 years ago. Examination of the nose shows no abnormalities. There are several bruises on the lower extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Platelet count
220,000/mm3



Bleeding time

9 minutes (N = 2–7)


Prothrombin time
13 sec


Partial thromboplastin time
50 sec


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bernard-Soulier Syndrome (BSS) is an autosomal recessive disorder that leads to platelet dysfunction. BSS is often asymptomatic but can manifest with epistaxis, easy bruising, prolonged bleeding time, and either a low or normal platelet count. However, BSS does not cause prolonged PTT.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemophilia A, an x-linked recessive disease with factor VIII deficiency manifests with recurrent epistaxis, episodes of heavy bleeding following medical procedures, bruises, and prolonged PTT. However, bleeding time would be normal since platelets are unaffected.

C) INCORRECT:

Factor X deficiency is a rare, autosomal recessive disease or can also be acquired from liver disease or vitamin K deficiency. This condition can also manifest with recurrent epistaxis and easy bruising. However, laboratory results would show prolonged PT and PTT due to factor X's involvement in the common pathway of the coagulation cascade. Additionally, bleeding time would be normal since platelets are unaffected.

D) INCORRECT:

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive disorder that prevents platelet aggregation. This condition typically manifests with mucosal bleeding (e.g. epistaxis). While a prolonged bleeding time is expected, further laboratory parameters are typically normal in Glanzmann thrombasthenia. This patient also has a prolonged PTT, making a different diagnosis more likely.

E) CORRECT:

Von Willebrand disease occurs when there is a deficiency or defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF). The deficiency hinders the ability of platelets to adhere to subendothelial collagen and inhibits platelet activation, which leads to a prolonged bleeding time. PT and PTT are generally in normal ranges in patients with this condition because the clotting factors are unaffected. However, factor VIII is bound to vWF in the blood to prevent rapid breakdown. Thus, half of the patients with vWD can also present with mildly prolonged PTT, as seen in this patient.

Desmopressin is the treatment of choice for vWD types 1 and 2 because it stimulates vWF release from endothelial cells. Desmopressin is not an effective treatment in type 3 because of the complete absence of vWF.
Image Description:

Red indicators link syndromes with their associated defective or absent molecules, according to which phase of primary hemostasis is affected (i.e., adhesion or aggregation)
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent epistaxis, a previous episode of heavy bleeding following tooth extraction, and multiple bruises. His laboratory studies show prolonged bleeding time despite normal platelet count and prolonged PTT. These features are consistent with the most common congenital hemostatic disorder.

questions.text:
A previously healthy, 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with persistent bleeding from his gums after an elective removal of an impacted tooth. Multiple gauze packs were applied with minimal effect. He has a history of easy bruising. His family history is unremarkable except for a maternal uncle who had a history of easy bruising and joint swelling. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
36%


Platelet count
170,000/mm3


Prothrombin time
13 sec


Partial thromboplastin time
65 sec


Bleeding time

5 min (N = 2–7)



Peripheral blood smear shows normal-sized platelets. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain types of von Willebrand disease can present with findings similar to those seen in this patient (mucosal bleeding, normal or ↑ PTT). However, von Willebrand disease also causes increased bleeding time, and it is autosomal dominant, meaning that one of the patient's parents would likely have a history of bleeding diathesis as well.

B) INCORRECT:

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an inherited disorder causing excessive bleeding, which often presents with mucosal bleeding or excessive postprocedural bleeding. However, Glanzmann thrombasthenia presents with normal PTT and platelet count, ↑ bleeding time, and isolated platelets without clumping on peripheral smear, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, Glanzmann thrombasthenia is usually diagnosed in infancy or early childhood.

C) CORRECT:

Excessive bleeding in an otherwise healthy young male who easily bruises, with a probable family history of the disease in a maternal uncle and isolated PTT elevation is highly suspicious for hemophilia. Because hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder, it affects males almost exclusively, and ⅔ of patients have a positive family history in a maternal male relative. The history of easy bruising and joint swelling (likely hemarthrosis) in his maternal uncle is characteristic of hemophilia. Inherited hemophilias cause isolated factor VIII, IX, or XI deficiency (all part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway), presenting with isolated PTT (which measures intrinsic pathway function) elevation on lab workup.

Because of his highly suggestive family history, the next best step for this patient is to acquire clotting factor activity levels to confirm the diagnosis. For patients with less suggestive histories, a mixing study would be the most appropriate next step. Hemophilia A is more common than hemophilia B; hemophilia C is the rarest type of hemophilia.

D) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenia can cause mucosal bleeding, which is seen in this patient. However, it is also associated with a low platelet count, petechiae, and sometimes prolonged bleeding time, none of which are present in this patient. Finally, immune thrombocytopenia more frequently affects children and women of childbearing age, rather than teenage boys.

E) INCORRECT:

Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an inherited disorder causing excessive bleeding that can present with similar symptoms. However, patients with Bernard-Soulier syndrome have a normal PTT,↑ bleeding time, and giant platelets on peripheral smear, none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old boy is hospitalized for refusal to bear weight and swelling of his right knee. His parents report that he has been standing and cruising for the past 6 weeks, but today he suddenly refused to stand and cried when attempting to put weight on his right leg. His parents do not recall any specific trauma. He had an upper respiratory infection last week. He was born at term via uncomplicated cesarean section, and he has had no previous hospitalizations or surgeries. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, his right knee is swollen and warm to the touch without erythema. Range of motion is restricted. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


Leukocyte count
16,700/mm3 (N = 6000–17,500/mm3)


Platelet count
173,000/mm3



C-reactive protein
2 mg/L


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
5 mm/hr


Prothrombin time
13.0 sec


Partial thromboplastin time
65.5 sec


A radiograph of the right knee reveals soft-tissue edema without fracture. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis in infants usually manifests with signs of systemic infection and septicemia. Cellulitis is often present, and features of joint involvement may be subtle. Septic arthritis is unlikely in this patient, who is afebrile and whose C-reactive protein level, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and leukocyte count are all normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Although failure to bear weight in a nonambulatory child should raise concern for nonaccidental trauma, this patient’s overall clinical picture — an abnormal PTT and localized symptoms without evidence of fracture — do not suggest abuse.

C) INCORRECT:

Ligament tears manifest with a swollen joint but are traumatic injuries that are more common in older children who can run. In addition, one would not expect abnormal laboratory findings with a ligament tear.

D) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis may manifest with joint pain, swelling, and warmth, usually after bacterial gastroenteritis or a streptococcal infection. It is not associated with an elevated PTT.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s laboratory findings are significant for a normal prothrombin time and an elevated partial thromboplastin time, consistent with hemophilia. The pain and swelling in his right knee is likely due to hemarthrosis, a common finding in hemophilia that is often described on plain-film radiographs as nonspecific soft-tissue swelling. Most patients with severe hemophilia show symptoms of the disorder in the first year of life. During the newborn period, common manifestations include cephalohematoma, intracranial hemorrhage, and bleeding after circumcision. As the child begins learning to walk, bruising and joint bleeds are more common.

Key learning point: Joint pain and swelling in a child with an elevated partial thromboplastin time is most consistent with a diagnosis of hemophilia.
questions.hint: Mixing studies may help confirm this patient's diagnosis.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with right knee swelling and difficulty bearing weight. He has had multiple episodes of painful joint swelling and excessive bleeding following a tooth extraction. Examination shows the knee is warm, swollen, and tender, with limited range of motion. Laboratory results show a normal platelet count, normal prothrombin time, and a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time that corrects with a mixing study.
Which of the following factor deficiencies is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Factor XII deficiency causes a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) that corrects with a mixing study but is not associated with bleeding in vivo. The patient's history of excessive bleeding and hemarthroses suggests a deficiency in factors critical for hemostasis, inconsistent with Factor XII deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Factor XI deficiency, or Hemophilia C, causes prolonged aPTT that corrects with a mixing study but usually presents with bleeding after trauma or surgery, not spontaneous hemarthroses. It is autosomal recessive, affecting both sexes equally, unlike the X-linked pattern seen in this male patient.

C) CORRECT:

Factor VIII deficiency, known as Hemophilia A, is an X-linked recessive disorder primarily affecting males. It manifests with recurrent joint bleeding (hemarthroses) and prolonged bleeding after procedures, such as dental extractions. Laboratory findings include a normal platelet count, normal prothrombin time, and prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) that corrects with a mixing study, indicating a factor deficiency rather than an inhibitor. Factor VIII is essential for the intrinsic tenase complex, crucial for thrombin generation and fibrin clot formation, explaining the bleeding tendency in affected individuals.

Key learning point: Hemarthrosis and joint contractures in a young male are classic signs of hemophilia, a bleeding disorder due to deficiency of clotting factors VIII or IX.

D) INCORRECT:

Von Willebrand disease involves impaired platelet adhesion and a defect in von Willebrand factor, leading to mucocutaneous bleeding rather than hemarthroses. Severe forms can prolong aPTT due to reduced factor VIII, but typically show abnormal bleeding time and specific assay abnormalities, not described here.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of a 6-month history of recurrent spontaneous nosebleeds. He reports that the bleeding usually stops within 10 minutes when he pinches his nostrils. He has no history of serious illness, but did experience prolonged bleeding after wisdom teeth extraction 2 years ago. Examination of the nose is normal. There are several bruises on his lower extremities. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Platelet count, blood
220 × 109/L (130–380)


Bleeding time (Ivy method), blood

9 min (1–9)


Prothrombin time (PT), blood
13 s (10–14)


Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), nonanticoagulated, blood

50 s (22–30)


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Factor X deficiency is a rare, autosomal recessive disease or can also be acquired from liver disease or vitamin K deficiency. This condition can also manifest with recurrent epistaxis and easy bruising. However, laboratory results would show prolonged PT and PTT due to factor X's involvement in the common pathway of the coagulation cascade. Additionally, bleeding time would be normal since platelets are unaffected.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemophilia A, an x-linked recessive disease with factor VIII deficiency manifests with recurrent epistaxis, episodes of heavy bleeding following medical procedures, bruises, and prolonged PTT. However, bleeding time would be normal since platelets are unaffected.

C) INCORRECT:

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive disorder that prevents platelet aggregation. This condition typically manifests with mucosal bleeding (e.g. epistaxis). While a prolonged bleeding time is expected, further laboratory parameters are typically normal in Glanzmann thrombasthenia. This patient also has a prolonged PTT, making a different diagnosis more likely.

D) CORRECT:

Von Willebrand disease occurs when there is a deficiency or defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF). The deficiency hinders the ability of platelets to adhere to subendothelial collagen and inhibits platelet activation, which leads to a prolonged bleeding time. PT and PTT are generally in normal ranges in patients with this condition because the clotting factors are unaffected. However, factor VIII is bound to vWF in the blood to prevent rapid breakdown. Thus, half of the patients with vWD can also present with mildly prolonged PTT, as seen in this patient.

Desmopressin is the treatment of choice for vWD types 1 and 2 because it stimulates vWF release from endothelial cells. Desmopressin is not an effective treatment in type 3 because of the complete absence of vWF.

Key learning point: Von Willebrand disease presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, prolonged bleeding time, and often mildly prolonged PTT due to defective or deficient von Willebrand factor affecting both platelet function and factor VIII stability.
Image Description:

Red indicators link syndromes with their associated defective or absent molecules, according to which phase of primary hemostasis is affected (i.e., adhesion or aggregation)

E) INCORRECT:

Bernard-Soulier Syndrome (BSS) is an autosomal recessive disorder that leads to platelet dysfunction. BSS is often asymptomatic but can manifest with epistaxis, easy bruising, prolonged bleeding time, and either a low or normal platelet count. However, BSS does not cause prolonged PTT.
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent epistaxis, a previous episode of heavy bleeding following tooth extraction, and multiple bruises. His laboratory studies show prolonged bleeding time despite normal platelet count and prolonged PTT. These features are consistent with the most common congenital hemostatic disorder.

questions.text:
You are seeing a previously healthy 16-year-old boy who is brought to the emergency department with persistent gum bleeding following elective removal of an impacted tooth. Multiple gauze packs have been applied with minimal effect. He has a history of easy bruising. His family history is notable for a maternal uncle with easy bruising and joint swelling. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit (Hct), blood
0.36 L/L (0.38–0.50)


Platelet count, blood
170 × 109/L (130–380)


Prothrombin time (PT), blood

13 s (10–14)


Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), nonanticoagulated, blood

65 s (22–30)


Bleeding time (Ivy method), blood
5 min (1–9)


Peripheral blood smear shows normal-sized platelets. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenia can cause mucosal bleeding, which is seen in this patient. However, it is also associated with a low platelet count, petechiae, and sometimes prolonged bleeding time, none of which are present in this patient. Finally, immune thrombocytopenia more frequently affects children and women of childbearing age, rather than teenage boys.

B) INCORRECT:

Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an inherited disorder causing excessive bleeding that can present with similar symptoms. However, patients with Bernard-Soulier syndrome have a normal PTT,↑ bleeding time, and giant platelets on peripheral smear, none of which are seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Certain types of von Willebrand disease can present with findings similar to those seen in this patient (mucosal bleeding, normal or ↑ PTT). However, von Willebrand disease also causes increased bleeding time, and it is autosomal dominant, meaning that one of the patient's parents would likely have a history of bleeding diathesis as well.

D) CORRECT:

Excessive bleeding in an otherwise healthy young male who easily bruises, with a probable family history of the disease in a maternal uncle and isolated PTT elevation is highly suspicious for hemophilia. Because hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder, it affects males almost exclusively, and ⅔ of patients have a positive family history in a maternal male relative. The history of easy bruising and joint swelling (likely hemarthrosis) in his maternal uncle is characteristic of hemophilia. Inherited hemophilias cause isolated factor VIII, IX, or XI deficiency (all part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway), presenting with isolated PTT (which measures intrinsic pathway function) elevation on lab workup.

Because of his highly suggestive family history, the next best step for this patient is to acquire clotting factor activity levels to confirm the diagnosis. For patients with less suggestive histories, a mixing study would be the most appropriate next step. Hemophilia A is more common than hemophilia B; hemophilia C is the rarest type of hemophilia.

Key learning point: Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder causing isolated prolonged PTT and bleeding due to deficiency of intrinsic pathway clotting factors, typically affecting males with a positive maternal family history.

E) INCORRECT:

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an inherited disorder causing excessive bleeding, which often presents with mucosal bleeding or excessive postprocedural bleeding. However, Glanzmann thrombasthenia presents with normal PTT and platelet count, ↑ bleeding time, and isolated platelets without clumping on peripheral smear, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, Glanzmann thrombasthenia is usually diagnosed in infancy or early childhood.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-year-old boy in the emergency department who presents with a 1-day history of pain and swelling in his right knee. There is no history of trauma. He was born at term and has been healthy. His maternal uncle has a history of a hematological disorder. His temperature is 37.1°C and pulse is 97/min. Examination of the right knee reveals erythema, swelling, tenderness, and limited range of motion. No other joints are involved. Knee x-ray shows an effusion without structural abnormalities. Arthrocentesis yields uniformly bloody synovial fluid. Which one of the following findings is most likely to be seen on further evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Prolonged partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is a diagnostic feature of hemophilia A, an X-linked recessive disease characterized by deficient factor VIII. A principal clinical feature is hemorrhage into a single weight-bearing joint, which can occur spontaneously or following minimal trauma. Repeated hemarthrosis can lead to joint destruction over time. Further hemorrhages may occur in the CNS, in gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts, and from mucous membranes. Blood tests also show normal prothrombin time and normal platelet count. The diagnosis is confirmed through mixing studies and quantitative assessment of factor VIII activity levels.

Key learning point: Hemarthrosis in young children, often due to hemophilia A, is characterized by a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) with normal prothrombin time and platelet count.

B) INCORRECT:

A prolonged prothrombin time indicates a disorder of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, specifically of fibrin formation. Causes include vitamin K deficiency, reduced or impaired production of coagulation factors (e.g., liver disease), and treatment with warfarin. Since spontaneous hemarthrosis is indicative of advanced liver disease or severe vitamin K deficiency, it is unlikely to be the first presenting symptom in a previously healthy child.

C) INCORRECT:

An elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate in a child with joint pain and restricted joint movement is suggestive of several underlying conditions, including juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) and septic arthritis. However, neither condition is associated with hemarthrosis. Moreover, JIA usually affects several joints with symptoms lasting ≥ 6 weeks and is associated with extra-articular symptoms (e.g., anterior uveitis).

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated hemoglobin S concentration is seen in patients with sickle cell disease (SCD), which can cause vaso-occlusive bone and joint pain but not true hemarthrosis. Synovial fluid in SCD-related painful crises is typically nonhemorrhagic. Moreover, SCD is autosomal recessive, and a positive family history in a maternal uncle alone would not fit the inheritance pattern.

E) INCORRECT:

The most common causes of thrombocytopenia include impaired platelet production (e.g., due to bone marrow failure, infections, malignancy) and increased platelet turnover (e.g., disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura). Symptoms of thrombocytopenia include easy bruising, mucosal bleeding, and petechiae if the platelet count drops below 30 × 109/L; hemoarthrosis due to thrombocytopenia alone is rare.
questions.hint: Factor VIII activity levels should be evaluated in a 3-year-old patient with hemarthrosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with known hemophilia A is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of acute knee swelling and pain after a minor fall at home. Physical examination shows a tense, swollen knee with limited range of motion. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Factor IX concentrate is used to treat hemophilia B, not hemophilia A. This patient has an established diagnosis of hemophilia A, which involves factor VIII deficiency, making factor IX concentrate inappropriate and ineffective.

B) INCORRECT:

Fresh frozen plasma contains all clotting factors, including factor VIII, but in low concentrations requiring large infusion volumes to achieve therapeutic levels. Specific factor VIII concentrate provides more targeted and effective treatment with lower volume requirements.

C) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin triggers release of stored factor VIII and is only indicated for mild hemophilia A. Desmopressin is insufficient in an acute bleeding episode with hemarthrosis.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Factor VIII concentrate is the specific treatment for patients with hemophilia A who are experiencing acute bleeding episodes. This patient has established hemophilia A and presents with hemarthrosis, and immediate factor VIII replacement is indicated to control bleeding and prevent joint damage.

E) INCORRECT:

Antifibrinolytic therapy inhibits clot breakdown and is used in addition to factor substitution, particularly for oral cavity procedures. Antifibrinolytic therapy does not replace the deficient factor VIII and is inadequate as sole therapy for acute hemarthrosis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for a painful, swollen right knee that began after a minor fall at home. His mother notes he has always bruised easily and had prolonged oozing after his routine immunizations. The boy’s father is healthy, but his maternal uncle has a known bleeding disorder. On examination, the boy is afebrile. His right knee is warm, edematous, and tender with a decreased range of motion. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 250,000/mm³, a prothrombin time (PT) of 12 seconds, and an activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) of 65 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for hemophilia A, an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of factor VIII. The family history of an affected maternal uncle is highly suggestive of this inheritance pattern. Clinically, hemophilia A is characterized by deep tissue bleeding, particularly hemarthrosis and intramuscular hematomas, often after minor trauma. The laboratory findings of a prolonged aPTT with a normal PT and platelet count specifically point to a defect in the intrinsic coagulation pathway, where factor VIII functions. Hemophilia B (factor IX deficiency) presents identically but is less common.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K is a necessary cofactor for the synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. A deficiency would therefore impair both the intrinsic (Factor IX) and extrinsic (Factor VII) pathways. This would result in a prolongation of both the PT and the aPTT. This patient has a normal PT, making this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and can cause easy bruising. However, it typically presents with mucocutaneous bleeding (e.g., epistaxis, gingival bleeding) rather than the deep joint bleeding seen in this patient. While the aPTT can be mildly prolonged if factor VIII levels are affected, spontaneous hemarthrosis is rare except in the most severe type (Type 3), and the inheritance is usually autosomal, not X-linked.

D) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the destruction of platelets. While it causes easy bruising, the primary laboratory finding would be thrombocytopenia. This patient's platelet count is normal. Furthermore, bleeding in ITP is typically superficial (petechiae, purpura), not deep hemarthrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Factor VII is a component of the extrinsic coagulation pathway. A deficiency in factor VII would cause an isolated prolongation of the PT with a normal aPTT. This patient's laboratory results show the opposite pattern (normal PT, prolonged aPTT).
